form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Sanders (for Mr. Welch (for himself, Mr. Sanders, Mr. Durbin, Mr. Van Hollen, and Mr. Merkley)) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs

form.official-title: To codify Executive Order 14115 imposing certain sanctions on persons undermining peace, security, and stability in the West Bank.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Sanctions and Accountability for Non-Compliance and Transparent Investigative Oversight for National Security in the West Bank Act or the SANCTIONS in the West Bank Act.

section.header: Codification of sanctions on persons undermining peace, security, and stability in the West Bank

subsection.text: United States sanctions provided for in Executive Order 14115 (50 U.S.C. 1701 note; relating to imposing certain sanctions on persons undermining peace, security, and stability in the West Bank), as in effect on January 19, 2025, shall—

paragraph.text: be in effect on and after the date of the enactment of this Act; and
remain in effect except as provided by subsection (c).

subsection.text: Effective on the date of the enactment of this Act, sanctions imposed under Executive Order 14115 and revoked by Executive Order 14148 (90 Fed. Reg. 8237) shall be reinstated.

paragraph.text: The President may terminate the application of sanctions described in subsection (a) that are imposed with respect to a person in connection with activity conducted by the person if the President submits to the appropriate congressional committee a notice that—

subparagraph.text: the person is not engaging in the activity that was the basis for the sanctions or has taken significant verifiable steps toward stopping the activity; and
the President has received reliable assurances that the person will not knowingly engage in activity subject to sanctions described in subsection (a) in the future.

paragraph.text: The President shall submit the notice required by paragraph (1) with respect to the termination of the application of sanctions with respect to a person—

subparagraph.text: except as provided by subparagraph (B), not less than 15 days before terminating the application of such sanctions; and
in the event of exigent circumstances, as soon as practicable, but in no event later than 3 business days after terminating the application of such sanctions.

subsection.text: In this section, the term appropriate congressional committees means—

paragraph.text: the Committee on Foreign Relations and the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs of the Senate; and
the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on Financial Services of the House of Representatives.
